GENERAL INFORMATION
Introduction
Well 25/8-109 and 25/8-10S T2 were drilled on the PL 027 license, location shown in Fig. 1.1 The 25/8-10S was drilled to test the Forseti prospect. After cutting one core the well was involuntarily sidetracked, the new wellbore is called 25/8-10S T2.
The well discovered oil in the Hermod and Middle Heimdal formations. After wireline logging the 25/8-10S T2 well was drill stem tested, 1727 - 1740.5 m mdrkb (1723.1 - 1736.4 mtvdss). If flowed 2600 STB/D of oil. The well was plugged and abandoned as an oil discovery.

1.4
Well Summary 25/8-10S and 25/8-10S T2
Well 25/8-10S and 25/8-10S T2 were drilled with Deep Sea Trym to test the Forseti prospect. The wells discovered oil in Hermod - Heimdal Fm, Fig. 1.1 shows the well location.
Fig. 1.2 shows the drilling curve, days vs. depth.
Well 25/8-10S spudded April 29, 1997. A 36" hole was drilled from 153,5 - 227,5 m. The 30" casing was set at 227 m. A 17 1/2" hole was drilled to 1091 m and the 13 3/8" casing was set at 1076 m.
The riser and BOP was run, the well was displaced to 11.0 ppg OBM. The 12 1/4" hole was drilled to 1094 m. The leakoff test was 14.1 ppg.
The 8 1/2" hole was drilled to the core point 1722 m using GR-Res-dir.
One 90' core was cut from 1722 - 1749,5 m mdrkb.
After the first core was cut, a 60 ft core barrel was run in hole, but was unable to pass 1090 m. A wiper trip was started, but the 8 1/2" bit was not able to pass the obstruction at 1090 m. Then a 12 1/4" bit was run in hole and drilled 1076-1095 m, this bit was pulled out of hole. The 8 1/2" bit was run in hole and drilled and reamed the obstruction until directional survey indicated the original hole had been sidetracked. A cement plug was set 1026 - 1244 m.
Sidetrack; 25/8-10S T2
On May 12, 1997, the sidetrack to a location 15 m away at reservoir level started. The cement plug was drilled out to 1160 m mdrkb with a 12 1/4" bit. This bit was pulled and 8 1/2" BHA with MWD-GR -Res was used to drill to corepoint, which was within 3 mTVD of base of core no. 1 in original hole. One 120 ft core was cut 1749 - 1786 m mdrkb (37 m).
The 8 1/2" hole was drilled to TD = 1890 m mdrkb (1858.8 m tvd ss) with 11.0 ppg OBM.
A wiper trip was done prior to running wireline logs, see section 3.4 for details. After logging, May 17th, 1997, the well was prepared for drill stem testing.
e, wayah., 1997
Q:REPORTS1258_10S.DOCIbm04.12.97 page 10
Drill Stem Testing:
A 7" liner was run to 1876.2 m mdrkb. The well was perforated 1727 - 1740.5 m mdrkb (1723.1 - 1736.4 m tvd ss) on May 23, 1997.
The total duration of the flow period was 30.3 hrs. Included in this duration is a total of five well shut-in's due to operational difficulties. The average rate was approximately 2600 STB/D. It was decided to end the flow period when the well was shut-in as a result of the burners going out due to sand production. The build-up period lasted 36.2 hrs. For a detailed description of the DST, see chapter 5.

FORMATION EVALUATION

3.1
Cuttings samples
Three sets of wet and two sets of dried samples and one canned geochemistry sample set were collected from this well.
3.2
Cores
3.2.1 Core intervals
One core, 90 ft, was cut in the 25/8-10S well. A second core was unsuccessfully tried, see section 1.4 Well Operations summary. One core, 120 ft, was cut in the 25/8-10S T2 well. 4" fluted inner aluminium barrels were used for these cores. Special corehandling with gypsum injection were used at wellsite.
Table 3.1 Cores
Well Core No. 25/8-10S Core no.
1 25/8-10S T2 Core no. 1
Interval mmdrkb 1722-1749.5 1749-1786
Cut 27.5 37
Rec 27.5 37
Detailed core descriptions are included in Appendix III and IV
3.2.2 Core description summary
25/8-10S, core no. 1 Encountered Hermod Fm. sand of Early Eocene - Paleocene (ET9A) age. The sands are fine to medium grained and moderately to well rounded and sorted. Homogenous, parallel laminated and cross bedded units are observed. The entire sand interval contain rounded and angular shale claşts, some are defining the bedding others are present in conglomerates and as rip up clasts. The size and shape of the shale claşts suggest erosion of underlying shale in nearby areas. The sands are interpreted to be deposited by turbidity currents in a sand rich channel margin environment and in amalgamated - non amalgamated channels, proximal to a channel axis. The Sele Fm shales are parallel laminated and are interpreted to be deposited as interbedded hemipelagic and turbedittic mudstones.
25/8-10S 72, core no. 1 Encountered mottled, hemipelagic ZIB and ZIA2 shales, and Middle Heimdal Fm, sands of Late Paleocene age (ET6 and ET5, ZIA2 Upper sand and ZIA2 Lower Sand). The sands are overall fine to medium grained, well-to moderately sorted and rounded. Faint laminations and dish structures are observed in both sands, although the ZIA2 Lower sand (ET5) is mostly homogenous in appearance. The sands are interpreted to be deposited by high density gravity flows within submarine channels or at the termination of a submarine channel complex.

3.5
Log Analysis
The main goal of this analysis is to compute average petrophysical values for the Heimdal sands drilled by the side-track in the Early-Eocene - Paleocene section. Based on the log-derived water saturation the oil-water contact was set at 1755.5 m tvdss (1785.2 m mdrkb), slightly above the Sw=100% level in order to exclude the oil below, considered residual. Schlumberger's forward modelling framework, ELANI, was used for this evaluation
3.5.1 Log Data Quality and Environmental Corrections
Both wells (original 25/8-10S and technical side-track 25/8-10S T2) were drilled with oil-based mud (OBM). The bit size was 8.5" over the zone of interest. In well 25/8-10S T2 a maximum deviation of 10.4 ° was recorded at 1,571 m mdrkb, with an average of 9.5 ° over the reservoir. The logs used in this interpretation were acquired by WALS in one run combining the following services:
- HDIL/MAC/ZDEN / CNC/SGL
The HDL "true resolution logs" are, as expected from raw induction measurements, affected by the thickness of the oil-bearing beds and the contrast with the surrounding high conductivity vertical resolution: the deeper the radial investigation, the more depressed the resistivity reading in the sands. The lack of reliable vertically-matched logs lead to use the LWD resistivities instead for the purpose of this CPI, after carefull depth-matching with the nuclear wilreline logs. The density log had to be depth-matched independently in some intervals. There is a 0.5 in. drift between the caliper readings in the casing before and after the logging to TD. The caliper log reads an average 0.75 in, above BS throughout the entire zone of interest. The planned water sample could not be acquired due to the RCI failure and the necessary fall-back to FMT.
3.5.2 Petrophysical Model and Inputs
Production test results reveal an oil density of 0.913 g/cc at 17 °C and a reservoir temperature 5 degrees lower than the regional value: 70 °C vs 75 °C. Figure 3.2 is a Pickett Plot over the Early Eocene - Paleocene section. In the absence of a water sample (see 3.5.1), the Balder area water salinity (46.15 ppk) is assumed. Force fitting (YonX) through aRw = 0.069 yields m = 1.88 for the cementation exponent. In the absence of RI measurements so far, the saturation exponent was kept at the same value.
The mineralogical model, is based on patterns and trends observed on the log responses and regional knowledge. Besides quartz and clay, it includes a mineral representing a mixture of feldspars and micas, which is mainly

Figure 3.4 shows the Thorium - Potassium X-plot over the same interval. The trends and the end-points specific to this data set are indicated.
ELAN "corrects" for the mineralogy and fluid effects automatically when computing the total and effective porosities. This is achieved by using all the relevant information from all the logs available and their corresponding tool response equations. For example, the theoretical response equation for the bulk density measurement takes into account the variable fluid mixture present in the invaded zone and the (also variable) mineralogy. This ensures the use of the correct effective fluid density and matrix density on a continuous depth by depth level basis. For an oil- and gas-bearing reservoir drilled with OBM, its response equation reflects the presence of OBM filtrate and light hydrocarbons in the volume investigated by the tool, as follows: PB = OP FL + (1-0) MA
= OS XoPw +0(1-Sxo -SOBM)PG +0(1-Sxo -SG)POBM
+ VMiP Mi where: 0,Sxo, SOBM, SG, VMi are petrophysical variables and pw. Mi, POBMPG are fixed, end-point parameters.
There is no need to calibrate the density with core data beforehand, nor to know the reduction factor to be applied to the raw core porosities to bring them back at NOP conditions. What is critical is the accuracy of the model (fluids and minerals) and its associated end-point parameter values. The total porosity is the sum of the effective porosity and the clay-bound water volume:
0 = 0 e + Swe and the bound water volume is a constant proportion (100% wet clay porosity) of the clay volume:
Swe = OT.cz Va The constant Øt,cl was chosen to correspond to a dry clay density of 2.65 g/cc. The OBM filtrate density value used in this analysis has been increased in the pay zone to 0.85 g/cc (from its nominal value of 0.80 g/cc) to reflect the diffusion and miscibility of the filtrate with the heavier oil in place. For the water-bearing Zone IA2 sands, the invasion is probably too shallow for the Rxo measurement to quantify it and feed the density equation with the right volume of OBM filtrate. Therefore the formation water density was decreased from its nominal value to 0.95 g/cc to take into account the presence of OBM filtrate in the zone investigated by the bulk density.

3.6
FMT Pressures and Samples, Pressure gradient
Pressures and fluid samples were taken with the Western Atlas Formation Multi Tester tool (FMT). Details are included in Appendix VII of this report.
One FMT run was made over the interval 1728 m md rkb - 1810 m md rkb. One sample was taken in the Zone IA2 Upper sand at 1762 m md rkb, 9 liters of oil and 0,189 cubic meters of gas were recovered. 35 pressure measurements were taken.
The free water level (FWL) is calculated to be at 1763.6 m tvd ss. This is 8.1 m deeper than the OWC at 1755.5 m tvd ss, based on wireline logs. The three first pressure measurements (obs. no 1-3, log file no 4-6) are excluded from the calculation of the oil gradient, due to fluctuating temperatures. The FWL calculated from the FMT pressures is not considered correct due to uncertainties in the pressure measurements discussed below. The FMT pressure summary plot is shown in Figure 3.6.
The FMT tool is sensitive to temperature variations and should have been stabilized before measurements were taken. However, the temperatures fluctuated 0.3-0.9 degrees Celsius during the first 8 pressure measurements. This can explain the bending trend observed in the upper part of the plot (Figure 3.6). Western Atlas considers only the three first pressure measurements as bad test data due to temperature unstability,
The tool has not been calibrated for close to one year which is considered the limit.
The pressures from the welltest could not be approximated to the FMT pressures.

Synthetic seismogram
A synthetic seismogram for well 25/8-10ST2 was constructed from finely blocked sonic and density data in order to get a good one-D model and seismic tie to the
well.
Seismogram from a 25 Hz synthetic over the Paleocene section is shown i Figure 4.1. Also shown is the time-depth relationship and the drift curve from the VSP checkshots derived which indicate a good linear relationship in the investigated interval.
The zero-phase negative pulse applied gives a negative reflection coefficient corresponding to a peak on the synthetic trace.
The synthetic trace tie to the seismic data (full-fold cube) suggest a time shift of 14 ms down relative to the seismic (Fig. 4.1a). This shift was determined through cross-correlation of the synthetic and seismic trace at well location, and gave a correlation coefficient of 0.757 for the interval between 1.65-1.85 seconds. Although the fairly high correlation coefficient, it is still a poor tie in the reservoir section (1.70-1.76 sec). Formation tops from Tab. 4.1 are posted at the well location. These tops are calibrated post-drill time and depth pairs.

VSP
Zero-offset normal incidence VSP data from the 25/8-10ST2 well was acquired by Read Well Services on May 17th, 1997. The survey was recorded from 320 m to 1880 m MD RKB.
The receiver array consisted of a main tool and three satellites, each containing a three component geophone cartridge. The seismic source employed was a 3 x 150 cu in sleeve gun. The gun was hung at a depth at 3.8 m, and had an operating pressure of 2000 psi. The near field monitor hydrophone was kept at an offset of 2.0 m.
Further details concerning acquisition and processing of the VSP data can be found in "Zero Offset VSP, Esso Norge AS, 25/8-10S" by Read Well Services.
The synthetic tie to the VSP corridor stacks, 30 hz and 60 hz bandwith, is shown in Fig 4.1 b) and c). Cross correlation between the VSP and the synthetic trace yields a similar correlation coefficient as the correlation between the full-fold seismic and the synthetic trace. For the 30 hz VSP a correlation coefficient of 0.755 is achieved, and 0.695 is the measured correlation coefficient between the synthetic and the 60 hz VSP, both with a downward synthetic shift of 4 msc.
Compared to the full-fold seismic data, the VSP visually gives a better tie in the interval of interest (1.7 - 1.85 sec). In particular the 60 hz VSP corridor stack reveals a slightly better resolution in the reservoir section (1.70 - 1.76 sec). This is shown in Fig. 4.3 where the VSPs (30 hz and 60 hz respectively) have been spliced in to the seismic line B-B (see Fig. 4.2 a for location), that runs along the well path. The VSPs are unshifted relative to the seismic.

4.2
Mapping and Interpreted Horizons
The main objective of the well was the submarine for sandstones of the Hermod and Heimdal Formations. The following horizons have been interpreted and time maps created:
Top Balder Fm Base Balder Fm Near Base Zone II Top IA2L Top Chalk.
Top Balder is carried in a peak on the full-fold seismic data (upper red reflector Fig. 4.3 and 4.4). Post-drill results and the new synthetic well tie indicates that the Top Balder pick should be in the lower most part of the peak doublet (Fig. 4.1 a).
Base Balder is characterized by a decrease in impedance from the overlying shales of the Balder Fm to the Paleocene shales below. This ties in a peak in the 25/8-10ST2 well. The Base Balder Fm (orange reflector in Fig. 4.3 and 4.4) is mapped with high confidence over the entire area (Fig. 4.5). The new seismic tie indicates that at the well location of 25/8-10ST2 Base Balder pick should be sitting in the lowermost part of the strong peak into the zero crossing (as indicated in Fig. 4.1 a). The seismic interpretation is then 4 ms higher at the well than the actual calibrated Base Balder tie. On the VSP data the Base Balder ties in the strong peak,
Overall the Base Balder tie is of good quality. This is of high importance since this horizon is the key horizon in the Forseti area. Due to lack of seismic character and lack of response at the top of the reservoir level (Top Zone II), the top reservoir was extracted from the Base Balder depth structure map, and added a variable shale isopach (Fig. 4.6).
Near Base Zone I is near the base of the main reservoir sand and is in the 25/8-1 and 25/8-3 wells tied into strong, well-defined peak. At the well location of 25/8-10ST2 the synthetic seismogram indicates that the near Base Zone II ties to a zero-crossing going down from a strong peak to a strong trough on the full-fold seismic data (yellow reflector in Fig. 4.3 and 4.4). In the pre-drill scenario this horizon was interpreted in the strong peak below, which implies a 24 ms upward shift of the tie in the post-drill case.
The tie between the VSP corridor stacks and the full-fold seismic data (Fig. 4.3) revealed the same shift of the near Base zone II pick, which ties to a broad trough on the VSPs (see also Figs 4.1 b and 4.1 c). As mentioned in chapter 4.1 the interval 1.70 - 1.76 sec, in which the near Base Zone II horizon is interpreted, has a very poor tie to the seismic data in general. Hence, the confidence of the near Base Zone II interpretation is of moderate to low confidence at, and around, the location of well 25/8-10ST2.

Top IA2 lower corresponds to the transition from a shale down into a high impedance sandstone (lower red reflector in Figs. 4.3 and 4.4). The reflector is tied to a strong trough on the seismic with moderate to high confidence over the area. However, some interference with the OWC in the area have been identified.
Top Chalk is carried in a well defined strong trough (dark blue reflector Figs 4.3). The time interpretation on the full-fold seismic cube of the ES9403 3D survey has a very high confidence. Correlation between the near offset seismic cubes of the E$9403 and the NH9301 surveys to the full-fold seismic of the ES9403 survey indicates however, some time stretch in the full-fold cube. Locally this tends to deepen the Top Chalk time interpretation, which seems to be the case at the location of well 25/8-10ST2. The comparison between the full-fold seismic and the VSP corridor stacks suggest a similar stretch (Fig. 4.3). At the well location the Top Chalk pick is 20 ms deeper on the full-fold seismic data than on the VSP.
Ongoing gather analysis and test-reprocessing have indicated potential errors in the initial processing flow that might have generated the time stretch and the localized deepened Top Chalk as seen on the full-fold seismic cube of the ES9403
3D survey.

5.1
Well Testing
A drill stem test of the upper sand interval, the Paleocene Zone II, was performed utilizing the semi-submersible drilling vessel Deep Sea Trym in the period 22-28 May, 1997. The objectives of the well test were:
(1)
Obtain information for reservoir description (kh, initial reservoir pressure and temperature, presence of no-flow or constant pressure boundaries, characteristics and distance to boundaries if present) Determine the nature of the formation fluids by obtaining representative formation fluid samples Obtain information on well productivity and potential for sand production If possible confirm communication with estimated STOOIP
(3)
(4)
A summary of the test periods is shown in Figure 5.1. The test consisted of a total of seven flow and build-up periods. The net Paleocene Zone II sand thickness was estimated at 8.3 mTVD from open hole logs. A 13.5 meter interval, from 1727.0 - 1740.5 m mdrkb (1698.6 - 1711.9 mTVDSS) was perforated with 4 5/8" OD, 12 shots per foot, 360° phasing tubing conveyed perforating system (TCP).
2
The plan was to perforate the well slightly underbalanced, but the bottomhole pressure was approximately 290 psi higher than the formation pressure at the time of perforation. The well remained shut-in 0.4 hours after perforation with the objective to obtain an additional estimate of initial pressure. However, since the well was perforated significantly overbalanced the pressure was still falling when the well was opened, and the well did not flow.
Base oil was bull headed into the perforations in an attempt to flow the well, but without success. It was then decided to pull the plug below the screen and run in with wireline guns to re-perforate the casing. However, the plug could not pass the cross-over above the screen and the plug had to be lowered back to the bottom of the screen. The plug could not be re-set, and the loose plug allowed for the sand production that later caused the well to be shut-in. A second attempt to flow the well by bull heading base oil into the perforations was made. The wellhead pressure increased and at 03:28 on May 25th the well started flowing.
Three short shut-in's occured in the early stage of the test. The target flow rate was 2600 STB/D. The 4th flow period lasted for 16 hours before a slug of water caused the flare to go out. An additional 12 hours of flow was obtained before sand production caused the flare to go out again. It was discovered that the separator was filled with sand and it was decided to end the flow test. The downhole shut in valve was closed 0.8 hrs into the subsequent build-up (6th build-up) which is considered to be the main build-up. The main build-up lasted for 36 hours.
After the main build-up the well was opened for the 7th flow period during which downhole sampling was performed. The rate during downhole sampling was 570 STB/D (average rate during the 7th flow period was 800 STB/D). The well test, was terminated after the 7th build-up period.

Analysis Methods All build-up periods in Figure 5.1 were analysed using PanSystem in order to determine initial pressure, formation permeability, and pressure regime of the reservoir. The results of these analyses are summarized here.
Generally the build-up data is displayed in a log-log plot in order to define the middle-time region (MTR). The log-log plot is also used to determine the reservoir geometry and pressure regime. During the MTR the reservoir appears infinite and the flow geometry around the well is radial. Reservoir permeability, extrapolated pressure, and skin are determined from the analysis of the MTR data displayed in a semi-log plot.
Of the seven build-up periods, only the 6th and 7th build-up period lasted long enough to be considered for analysis. However, since the well was shut-in at the choke manifold at surface the early build-up data is dominated by wellbore storage/afterflow effects. Consequently it has not been possible to identify the

MTR with reasonable confidence for either of the build-up periods. Instead the results presented in this report are based on the following:
(a) Reservoir pressure regime from: (1) log-log plots of the 6th and 7th
build-up periods, (2) interpretation of the drawdown performance of the 6th flow period, and (3) GOR and well head pressure performance during
the 6th flow period. (b) Reservoir permeability from McKinley type curve analysis. (c) Reservoir pressure from FMT pressure points. (d) Reservoir temperature from maximum recorded temperature during flow.
Conventional Build-up Analysis Figure 5.6 is a log-log plot of the 7th build-up period. The MTR is defined by a zero slope pressure derivative curve. The wellbore storage flow regime is defined by the unit slop line in Figure 5.6. The "hump" immediately after the pressure data starts to deviate from the unit slope line is often referred to as the "wellbore storage hump". During this period wellbore effects still affect the data and generally the MTR is not interpreted to start before the end of the wellbore storage hump. As shown in Figure 5.6 a horizontal line can be drawn starting approximately 0.6 hours into the build-up. However, the interpreted MTR from the 7th build-up is not confirmed by a similar behavior for the 6th build-up (the log-log plot of the 6th build-up period shows a smooth transition from the interpreted end of wellbore storage to a -2 slope line and thus a horizontal line cannot be defined with reasonable confidence).
The downdip of the pressure derivative curve in Figure 5.6 resulting in a slope of approximately -2 is consistent with the pressure response from a reservoir with a gas cap and pressure support (either from the gas cap or from an aquifer). Presence of free gas was indicated by an increase of the wellhead pressure (indicating reduction of the density of the fluid in the wellbore) associated with an increase in the GOR from approximately 200 scf/stb to more than 500 scf/stb at the end of the 6th flow period.

McKinley Type Curve Analysis Afterflow still affects the data through the wellbore storage hump. McKinley (reference (41) describes a way to analyze pressure build-up data distorted by afterflow using type curves. The method requires a minimum of assumptions and yields a number for the permeability. If the well is not significantly damaged the McKinley permeability should provide a good estimate of the reservoir permeability. Figure 5.8 shows the McKinley type curve analysis of the 7th build-up. The estimated reservoir permeability is 4000 md. The estimated permeability is consistent with results from the McKinley type curve analysis of the 6th build-up.

Future Work
Based on the results presented in this report, it is recommended to perform a reservoir simulation study to history match the Forseti test. The objective of such a study would be to evaluate the possible range of gas cap sizes which wil be an important input to a field development study.
Conclusions
Based on the test of the Paleocene Zone II interval in the Hermod - Middle Heimdal formation performed in well 25/8-10S T2 over the period 22-28 May, 1997, the conclusions are:
(1)
The pressure response is consistent with a reservoir model with a gas cap and pressure support (either from a gas cap or from an aquifer). The presence of a gas cap was supported by GOR and wellhead pressure behavior.
The tested Forseti reservoir is unconsolidated with high porosity (32%) and a high permeability (4000 md).
References
/3/ 14/
Dake, L.: "New Concepts in Reservoir Engineering" McKinley, R.M.: "Wellbore Transmissibility from Afterflow-Dominated
Pressure Build-up Data", JPT July 1971.

5.2 PVT Analysis
PVT sampling were performed both at the test separator and downhole. A total of 3 PVT sets were collected at the test separator (each set consists of a 774 cc oil sample and a 20 liters gas sample). A total of 5 downhole PVT samples (600 cc) were collected. In addition the following samples were collected at the test separator:
16 x 18 liters oil samples at atmospheric pressure for rheology/wax analysis, emulsion analysis, crude assay, and special core analysis. 4 x 1 liters oil samples at atmospheric pressure for trace analysis. 4 x 0.5 liters oil samples at atmospheric pressure for the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate. 3 x 208 liters oil samples at atmospheric pressure for back-up. 2 x 774 cc oil samples at separator pressure for rheology/wax analysis, 2 x 20 liters gas samples at separator pressure for hydrate analysis.
(d) (e) (f)
A complete description of surface sampling is provided in ref./1/. The analysis of the samples is ongoing at CoreLab in Aberdeen.
